header.title: Beyond look & feel
header.subtitle: A guide to Celcom's Voice & Tone

content.title: Celcom content style guide
content.description: The Celcom Content Style Guide serves as a directory to aid every copy creator for Celcom to be cohesive and align with the overall tone and way of writing of the brand. This ensures that every customer touchpoint and interaction with Celcom is uniform, allowing for a better user experiences.

content.title: For Celcomers
content.description:
For Celcom staff, affectionately known as Celcomers, this guide represents our communication style across all platforms. While this guide will mainly focus on English content, some stylistic preferences can also be applied to other languages (e.g. Malay) used on our platforms as we constantly improve accessibility to every Malaysian.
 
This content style guide will cover all the bases in crafting your message the Celcom way: from understanding basic grammar rules to encouraging empathetic messaging to our diverse customer base.
 
This guide is the standard you should apply in your writing for Celcom.

content.title: Writing Goals and Principles
content.description:
As the pioneer of Malaysia’s telecommunication industry, our content style constantly evolves according to the times. Our writing goals and principles are aligned with our values of putting the people first as we advance with the latest wave of technology.
 
We create content based on these principles:
 
1. Nurture – We communicate with our customers to build long-lasting relationships. Our language is conversational and friendly, ensuring that empathy is at the forefront of every message.
 
2. Empower – We encourage our customers to understand and maximise the technology they’re using in their daily lives. Our messaging must aim to educate our customers, from newbies to the tech-savvy, or clarify anything related to our services, no matter how complex.
 
3. Respect – We avoid hard-sell, vague or exaggerated language because we respect our customers’ time spent with us. Our message is always clear and straight to the point because maintaining their trust is more important than any single promotion.

content.title: Voice and Tone
content.description:
Differentiating voice and tone may be difficult but remember: voice is constant while tone changes according to the context of the messaging.
 
Our voice is confident yet conversational. The Celcom brand is fresh and contemporary so our language must reflect the same. However, as Celcom has a variety of products, the tone, manner and word choice must be adjusted for the target audience.
 
Writing for Celcom Postpaid products – Presenting a family-friendly vibe, the tone is enthusiastic yet easygoing for working adults.
Writing for Celcom Xpax Prepaid products – Bright and exciting, our communication is dynamic with sprinkles of youthful buzzwords to appeal to a younger audience.
Writing for Celcom Business – Appealing to experts and doers, our tone is composed and welcoming, offering substantial communication with polish and data.

content.title: Word Choices
content.description:
Word choice is key in setting the tone for each audience. Aside from specific keywords that are part of Celcom’s content format, your word choice can be flexible as long as it fits the tone.
 
For example, when communicating a negative message, use optimistic word choices to soften the tone:
 
PreferredAvoid
Your download was not successful.Your download failed.

 
The length of the copy should also be as short as possible, while still delivering a more empathetic message.
 
Familiarise yourself with the local culture, traditions and colloquialisms to respect potential sensitivities, especially when your content uses local languages and dialects.
 
PreferredAvoid
Anda tidak memenuhi syarat kelayakan pendahuluan kredit.Anda tidak layak untuk pendahuluan kredit.

 
In the Malay copy example, saying the customer did not fulfil the requirements of a service (“tidak memenuhi syarat kelayakan”) is preferable compared to informing the customer that they are not eligible (“tidak layak”) as the term “layak” has negative connotations.
 
As our customers come from all walks of life, our word choice must convey our people-centric writing goals and principles.

content.title: Writing to Our Customers
content.description: As the pioneering telco service provider with the widest network in Malaysia, our customer base is diverse. So, our content should also reflect this diversity through inclusive and accessible language.

content.subtitle: Addressing our audience
content.description: When addressing the customer, always use the second-person pronoun “you” and/or using the term “customer”. Remember: the term “Celcomers” refers only to Celcom staff.

content.quote:
You can now experience ultra-fast 5G connectivity on Celcom's widest network. Please ensure you use a 5G compatible device within the coverage area.
 
You can also use the term “user” when you are writing functional copy related to the products or services.
 
Each user may only register up to 5 prepaid numbers.

content.title: Grammar and Mechanics
content.description:
On all our platforms, Celcom uses the AP style for a basic set of rules to standardise our content style. The AP style ensures a clean, uncluttered approach to writing. We also use UK English across the board.
 
UK English SpellingUS English Spelling
The spelling “maximise” follows the UK spelling.The spelling of “sanitizing” is American English. It must be changed to “sanitising”.
For more information on how to differentiate between UK and US English, click here to learn more.

content.title: Style & Formatting
content.subtitle: Customer-facing Language
content.description:
Save the technical jargon only for internal documents. Replace unfamiliar jargon with customer-facing language. This means spelling out abbreviations and using more familiar terms or phrases.
 
PreferredAvoid
Length of StayLOS
Switch to CelcomMNP
Mobile NumberMSISDN

content.subtitle: Capitalisation
content.description:
We use different rules of capitalisation, depending on the type of copy.
 
When writing headers, whether for a website banner or a title of an article, we always use sentence cases for capitalisation.

Sentence case capitalise the first letter of the first word only, apart from proper nouns.
 
However, when it comes to functional copy that appears multiple times, such as CTAs like “Read More”, we use title case instead.

Title case capitalise the first letter of each word, except for articles, short prepositions and conjunctions.
 
While these capitalisation rules are fixed, we allow room for flexibility when it comes to commercial copy. You may use all caps to garner attention to the copy.

We also capitalise certain terms that are related to the telecommunication industry:
 
  • Internet
  • WiFi

content.subtitle: Numbers
content.description: Use numerals for numbers even when you are indicating a single-digit number. However, spell out the number if it begins a sentence.
Numbers with more than 3 digits should include a comma.
You can also use shortened forms, such as “k” (for thousand) and “mil” (for million), for a commercial copy.

content.subtitle: Dates
content.description:
When inserting dates for functional copy, such as for billing, use dd/mm/yyyy: 19/04/2022.
 
When inserting dates for commercial copy, such as promotional ads, use Date-Month-Year: 31 December 2022.

content.subtitle: Money
content.description:
If you are writing about money, remember to include “RM” in front of the numerals with no space in between. You can write up to 9 digits, including 2 decimal points.
 
RM1,234,567.89.
 
You can exclude the number of cents if it is 0. On the other hand, if you are writing a value that is less than RM1, you must still include “RM” in the copy.
 
RM20
RM0.20

content.subtitle: Punctuation
content.description:
While your copy should follow the basic grammar rules of punctuation, you can ensure your copy remains short by replacing certain words with punctuation. This only applies to commercial copy so it can be visually engaging.
 
You can replace “and” with “&”.
Replace “at” with “@”.
Instead of “per”, use “/”.

Another way to enhance your copy visually is to use punctuation to emphasise your message.
 
Generally, we do not include any punctuation at the end of titles, headings and subheadings, except for question marks (?) and exclamation marks (!).

header.title: Celcom Life 3.0
header.subtitle: A revamp project intended to kill 3 birds with one stone

content.title: Prologue
content.subtitle: About Celcom
content.description: Celcom is an organisation with 3,000+ employees committed to bringing forward the national agenda of developing the capacities and capabilities of Malaysian society. Celcom has the widest network in Malaysia with a population coverage of 95% for 2G, 93% for 3G and 90% for 4G/LTE networks. It provides both prepaid and postpaid mobile and digital services with close to 9.1 million subscribers.

content.subtitle: My Journey with Celcom
content.description:
I landed as a Product Designer at Celcom in July 2018. It was an exciting time when Celcom was undergoing a substantial digital transformation (with IBMiX), introducing and developing multiple digital products (Portal, App, e-Commerce, Retail).
 
As a Product Designer assigned to the mobile application track, my initial primary scope was to lead in participatory requirements gathering sessions and analyse stakeholder interviews to understand key success factors for a project or pursuit, and translate them into functional solutions (journeys, screen flows, and low and high fidelity prototypes).
 
While we entered the post-revamp era along with digital transformation for the company’s mobile app, Celcom life 2.0 quickly received cosmetic (with dashboard and pay bill journey overhaul) upgrades over 1.0. Not long after BAU with mobile application track, familiarising myself with how business and the app works, I came across challenges that slowed (and blocked) us from becoming a great product.

content.title: Challenge #1:
content.subtitle: Business and Design challenges: Celcom Life 2.0 itself
content.description: IBMiX team was chasing deadlines with the 2.0 revamp; the revamp was built on top of legacy in hybrid mode, most of the features were just reskin and mirrored over 1.0. This exposed the app to multiple threats:

content.quote:
Performance

  • Stitch and patch on top of legacy caused sluggishness and received a lot of complaints from users (though the lag was not caused by design, it is part of the experience).

Scalability

  • Dial-based non-scrollable dashboard is clean, aesthetic, and basic; it has limitations to scale (e.g: each time a new requirement comes in, entries from the bubble button had to give way; business always had to fight for the only real estate ).
  • And because it failed to cater to the requirements, the decline stage of the product life cycle hit just after 6 months of deployment and struggled in hitting the expected in-app transaction KPI.

Lack of innovation

  • The revamp focused too much on UI and cosmetics, while usability issues were not treated properly, leaving a huge room for improvements (obtained from qualitative and quantitative findings which I will further elaborate below).

content.title: Challenge #2:
content.subtitle: Old ways of working + low UX maturity
content.description:
Celcom as a 30-year-old telco was at its early stage of transformation; most verticals (especially business units) were too embedded in a waterfall way of working. The digital team, as the ONLY department that adopted the Agile way of working, faced difficulty and resistance working with other verticals. There was low (or no) design maturity throughout the organisation. Again, due to deadline chasing, there was not enough design advocation and education done.
 
Even though the IBMiX team introduced personas to help put Business Owners in users’ shoes, most owners ignored the importance and value of user experience. This made it particularly tough for the Agile team to sprint and push through user-friendly journeys when we always got “we/business want...” over “our customers need...” when it came to requirement discussions.

content.title: Challenge #3:
content.subtitle: Design team structure and operations
content.description:
From the mobile application track, I observed that the design team structure and operation in an Agile setup within a traditional organisation was weird and rather awkward.
 
Each designer was assigned to a dysfunctional team that ran different design processes, using different design tools. This resulted in different maturity and quality towards design outputs, even with (in-use) design system; worse, it widened the gap in product design consistency.

content.quote:
My reflection as a product designer

Celcom Life and the digital products have, and deserve a greater possibility, I need to help unlock them.

“I can propose a revamp within my vertical to help fix them all (can I?)”

content.title: Putting thoughts into action
content.description:
This was (sort of) an inside-out kinda plan.
 
1. First, I needed to put on a cool proposal to justify the need for revamping (again) only after a year of the previous “revamp”.
 
2. Drive UX maturity along with the revamp.
 
3. Introduce and enforce a new design process that I can validate through the revamp and prove it fits the organisation’s working module.
 
They all seemed impossible but my dedication and determination to improve the situation persuaded me to give it a shot anyway.

content.subtitle: Envisioning 3.0
content.description: The plan was to start with a proposal of a 3.0 revamp that was strong, solid, and unquestionable by all means. I took one small step at a time, starting with concept and prototype creation on top of the existing 2.0.

Alongside, countless studies on Adobe Analytic and Verbatim Curation were done (take note, all the effort and amount of work done without knowing the plan will still come through for you!) to understand motivation and frustration from users’ standpoint while defining gaps and room for improvements.

content.subtitle: UX Maturity up-lifting plan
content.description:
There are 6 different stages when it comes to Design Maturity and Celcom was at stage 2 at that time and needed an uplift.
 
Based on Factors in UX Maturity ****by Nielsen Norman Group (basically where I got the spark for how a revamp can help overcome all the challenges), I outlined the key pillars and initiatives that needed to be done to tick the boxes to achieve UX maturity:

Vision: bring maturity up to stage 5
 
Guidance: roadmap

Operation and process: alignment
 
Consistency assurance: tools, design system, documentation

Design onboarding: design intro sessions, design workshops
 
Enforcement: user story crafting, story prioritisation

Measurement: metrics, pre-post design implementation
 
Continuous improvement: UX debt, design showcase

content.subtitle: Proposal of the idea
content.description:
I am grateful to have received the blessing from my Head of Design, Lim Zee King, and the Head of Mobile App at that time, Chin Wye Jin to further pursue the plan.
 
The Head of Mobile App assisted in filling up the improvement plans for app performance + technical scalability. Together, we put on a 360 proposal to Chief Digital Officer Dave Morrow.

The proposal was 360 except for the budgeting part (which is beyond my pay grade). We were being challenged left right up down, from necessity -> practicality -> impacts towards all aspects. The Head of Design and Head of Mobile were so persistent in unblocking everything to help surface the plan to the CEO.
The session went really well and was encouraging. We got our buy-in a few months after the presentation (a lot of justifications with various verticals), and were finally able to put it into action.

content.subtitle: The Revamp
content.description:
To keep this article short, I will be deep-diving into the revamp design processes in another article.
 
Click here if you would like to find out more! (not compiled for the time being, coming soon)

content.title: Outcome #1
content.subtitle: Celcom Life 3.0
content.description:
With the right execution for the revamp process (In Design: emphasise -> define -> ideate -> prototype -> validate), we helped elevate the app experience within the key pillars (performance, scalability, innovation). It led Celcom Life 3.0 towards tremendous results after launching in 2020.
 
One of the key results that can be directly related to UX/Design is our Apple App Store and Google Play Store rating.

Although we faced resistance (user adaptability) in the early stage of the launch, with continuous in-app onboarding and education, the new app eventually received good compliments on user-friendliness and this reflected in the high App Store and Play Store rating compared to the previous version. (the previous version was at 2.1 ~ 2.8).
 
The app tNPS score soared by +5 points too.

content.title: Outcome #2
content.subtitle: Organisation-wide UX Maturity
content.description:
We were able to uplift the organisation’s UX maturity to 3 - 4 ish from 2. A revamp project itself certainly can’t have that kind of impact, what’s important is the ripple effect that comes along after showing the results of how design can bring ACTUAL value to the business.
 
With the new guiding principle (Design for Availability, Scalability, and Maintainability) aligning with the pillars’ enhancement, we were able to bring (most of) the stakeholders on the same page, strike a sweet balance between user needs and business goals while carrying on design activities alongside the 3.0 revamp process.

The 3.0 revamp set a strong benchmark for the development (& design) processes, assuring consistency and driving results. It gave confidence and a strong shot for the senior management to further pursue a lean and agile (of course a more user and design-centric) way of working across the organisation, and later on, introduced a GTM module for a faster go-to-market pace with business.
 
Celcom is at the stage where we want to achieve consistency over efficiency and performance.

content.title: Outcome #3
content.subtitle: Design Team
content.description:
TBH, the 3.0 revamp didn’t fully lead to an expected outcome for the design team.
 
Although a complete design process was introduced and proven to work with the 3.0 revamp, we had very limited time for the enforcement. It took us some time to build up the Design System 2.0 to move everyone towards the new process, and not long after that, we had to restructure and repurpose some designers to serve the GTM module. This widened the design team’s gap in terms of purpose, scope, and deliveries.

content.title: Epilogue
content.description:
This was one of the most thrilling and interesting projects I embarked on (by myself) in Celcom. I am grateful to have been given the trust and empowerment to realise this revamp plan.
 
Along the way, I received full exposure to end-to-end app development, which further helped me especially when I needed to convey my thoughts and ideas to multiple parties in a discussion (business, designers, developers, QA, SA). I am now able to speak their language and make meetings more efficient.
 
Out of the digital team, I have built trust with various business stakeholders. I learned business and numbers from them, and this made my design proposal more inclusive and persuasive.
 
Another key thing I learnt is, to prove design values in business we need to be persistent (the way of work, the design method we use, the continuous advocation), and we should never compromise with any parties.
 
And that is how I was selected as an Axiata Champion 2021 for Above and Beyond.

header.title: Transitioning from Graphic Design to UX Design
header.subtitle: Is that for you?

content.description:
Here is a little background: I was a graphic designer at a single marketing agency for 10 years. People came and went but I stayed, one because I liked my colleagues but mostly because I loved what I did. It was the intensity of the ideation process and the adrenaline rush of the pitch that kept me going. The execution after not so much but it was still exciting to see your idea come to fruition.
 
Having said that, a year and half ago I was presented with the opportunity to try out a distinctive design field — user experience or UX as it is affectionately known in the industry. After giving it some thought, I took it because it was the Design Lead in Celcom himself who recruited me, and I was surprised I passed the challenging entry process to join the company.
 
Having said that, if ever you find yourself being given the opportunity to transition and needed some idea on what goes on behind the digital wall, here is a little sneak behind the curtain for you.

content.title: Journey to be in UX UI role
content.description:
Every one of us likes to see beautiful things, pleasant designs, and fascinating movies. Design in these things is a crucial element to me, as I tend to imagine how things can be even greater by injecting more thought to it. That is how I started my journey as a designer.
 
Back in 2020, upon being reached out to, I decided to begin my pivot from a graphic designer to UX designer. I spent months preparing for the job as a UX designer by picking up Adobe XD, learning new skills to design mobile app user flows, and creating a portfolio to demonstrate not just my design skills but design thinking, customer experience (CX) and end-to-end journey experiences. This is done through adapting to the terms of the world of UX, repurposing my knowledge as a graphic designer to a UX designer by recognising problems or opportunities, bug fixes and iterating until the best solution (for the moment) is found.

content.title: Difficulties when first joined as a UX designer
content.subtitle: Creativity in Advertising vs UX
content.description:
The primary goal of a UX designer is to shape the usability of a product over aesthetic design when designing an experience for the end users. We construct wireframe design and prototypes to convey the message that we want to deliver to stakeholders. It’s a visual storytelling over siloed designs.
 
As for graphic design, it is commonly associated with branding, marketing, and advertising of certain products or services. The idea is to create overall aesthetic of an artwork and focus on the visual elements.
 
It is usually a lengthier process for UX design, where we need to gather requirements, go through design thinking process, user testing, stakeholder management, and so on. Logical thinking plays a key role here; however, even though everything will be controlled, creativity still matters as I will explain.
 
Keeping in line with the consistency of a predetermined component design guideline is crucial for UX. Usually called design system, the guideline is generally overseen by a design system team that governs the consistent experience across all touch points of an organisation. That is how I can repurpose the creativity I harnessed as a graphic designer, by applying my previous creative experiences to create expressive icons and . Nonetheless, ultimately the imagination in UX must still be rooted in practicality. There is also no such thing as a Final Artwork for UX Designers — there is always room to grow and evolve a product.

content.subtitle: Understanding what UX in any industry is about
content.description:
After joining as a UIUX designer in Celcom, it took me some time to adapt to the unfamiliar environment and I quickly realised that I was clearly a newbie in the UIUX design field. Ways to overcome the lack of skills and knowledge is to learn with an open mind and to ask a lot of questions to gain a greater understanding of what is expected in the role.
 
Start by always being curious and take part in webinars to get a deeper understanding of UX and to develop your skills. A good place to get up to date with UIUX trends would be via designers from YouTube, dribbles, and Behance to name a few.

For example, once you are skilled, you can get creative with the assigned requirements of a journey by figuring out how to combine multiple steps or to craft the shortest user journey. Once, when I found myself in such a situation, it required multiple review sessions with internal teams and user testing sessions to be sure the journey I proposed is successful based on the requirements. Upon presentation of our findings to the stakeholders, we were able to convince them with the proven stats and data that 2 different journeys on the Celcom Life could be streamlined into a single journey without duplication of work by the developers and other team members.
 
By always practising the design thinking processes, upcoming projects will run smoothly with everyone having a better understanding of the UIUX designer’s processes as well as the organization’s workflow and what to be expect in the future.

content.subtitle: Cultural differences
content.description:
Are you still wondering what people in UX actually do? Coding? Website? Apps? To be honest, people tend to be confused of what UX actually is.
 
Being part of the BAU (Business As Usual) team in the Digital department as well the GTM (Go to Market) team, the pace of working is fast while still adhering to the processes, which means that everything will be done in due time. All tasks follow an agreed methodology, like user research, wireframing, prototyping and reviewing with various stakeholders (channel owners, senior designers, writers). Final version or iteration of a journey would be close to the expected outcome, with the data and test results serving as backups.

This is contrary to the agency life, where I am familiar with having our ideas being shot down or axed way before it ever reaches to the client. We often have such limited time that we don't get to create user personas, user journey mapping and validating designs through testing especially for last minute clients briefings expecting a quick turnaround time.
 
However, graphic designers who had to go through that ‘hell’ (a hard time) come out on the other side with a more competitive edge and hardened against rejections.

content.title: Silver Linings
content.subtitle: Design skills are transferable
content.description:
It is important to know that between the roles of a UXD and GD, there are still several concept similarities. Design is for everything that caters to the mass market, and both require communication skills, storyboarding, and of course, design skills. Both types of designers should also have a strong knowledge of graphic-based computer software and systems.
 
Most important of all is stay open minded and ready to constantly absorb new information and latest design trends. Also, no matter how good the UX of a product is, advertising is the wings that will take your product to new heights.

content.subtitle: Thoughts
content.description:
To round it up, I am fortunate that I have learnt the skillset as a graphic designer to build a strong foundation to be able to be where I am today.
 
To be needed in the ‘market’ solely depends on your own capabilities, No matter where we are today, the only thing that doesn’t change is the ‘present’ and we have to always make that count.
 
Never stop exploring.
